replies.context:
In careful steps from 2014 to 2019, engineers at JPL demonstrated that it was possible to build an aircraft that was lightweight, able to generate enough lift in Mars' thin atmosphere, and capable of surviving in a Mars-like environment. They tested progressively more advanced models in special space simulators at JPL. In January 2019, the actual helicopter that is riding with Perseverance to the Red Planet passed its final flight evaluation. Failing any one of these milestones would've grounded the experiment.

Looks like the Drone was engineered by NASA engineers from scratch.

Thanks.
The standard drone propellers wouldn't bite enough air to assure lift. So they used a stacked wide-blade helicopter system suitable to the thin atmosphere.
Drones usually have 4 or more rotors positioned at the corners whereas a helicopter has a central rotor or pair of counterrotating rotors on a shaft in the center of mass.

I‚Äôve learned so much about drones and helicopters today.
Thanks. I stand corrected.
The two terms are not mutually exclusive.
Okay. Thanks.

context: Ingenuity, the long lost Wright brother, is going to be collecting data for aerodynamic modeling - got to be.  Gravity, and atmospheric pressure conditions on Mars are bit of a theoretical reach to duplicate on earth. Now comes the pay off.  With actual data the NASA models can/will be refined, and absolutely priceless knowledge will be banked for future missions.  Geology and  climatology are interesting exercises in basic science, but aerodynamics is applied engineering with potentially huge payoffs.

context: Many (100's or 1000's) of us who fly RC of all types have suggested RC drones be used on Mars missions for years and years. 100rds  and even 1000snds of times more efficient for all things evolving reconnaissance then any wheeled vehicle would ever be. Now if they can actually use it and not just let it set while they dream about using it, they may have something there.

replies.context: There are millions of drones, but for Mars, this helicopter is a better choice.

Everything seems easy when you don't know much about it.
The MAXIMUM atmospheric density on mars is equivalent to 115,000 feet altitude on earth.  There is a good reason you don't see helicopters (or fixed wing aircraft) fly at that altitude - is incredibly difficult (and inefficient).  
You get an advantage of 2.66 due to lighter gravity  on mars, but the air density is 72 times less.  That means that rotors on mars have to work 27 times harder than on earth.  It's a very challenging environment to fly in.

So NASA made a mistake then with expecting to have this aircraft fly huh? Some people seem set on stating the impossible, then those who do not listen to such people, do the impossible. Also, you seem to not understand the concept of RPM. You do realize the faster the RPM the more the thrust on any propeller system . You must also not realize the less dense the higher the RPM can be for the same power requirement. I don't actually see at all what you are attempting to project here. The fact of the matter is, It will fly! How well will depend on numbers of variables and how responsive the equipment is to all of them on it's own.

The conclusion you draw from what I posted clearly show you are quite challenged in the critical thinking department.  So it's no surprise that you don't see what I am trying to say.  I  will  dumb it down some more for you:  I said that flying in the Martian atmosphere is very challenging.  I put some numbers to some of the basic variables to quantify the level of challenge - 27 times harder just to get off the ground.  That's a lot.  Not impossible, but very difficult.
As for understanding the "basic variables" as you say, I am what they call a "subject matter expert" in this area.  I have had a long career as a technical lead in  flight dynamics for a major aerospace company, and served as the lead systems engineer for a (international) missile systems company.  I also specialize in low Reynold's number flight regimes, (even sub-critical).  I have designed and constructed my own custom propellers, so I understand the variables.  I have experience conducting tests at every major US test range, and in 10 different wind tunnel facilities across the US and Canada.    And what I am implying in my original post is that your experience with toy helicopters simply does not equip you to understand the nature of the challenges involved with mars flight.

context: Yawn. And moments after completing all this  (probably unnecessary?) testing since landing.. something will probably break or batteries will stop functioning, right? Just get ON WITH IT ALREADY!

replies.context:
You sound jaded, and that's sad to see. I wonder if you have any idea how much intelligent planing and dedication by thousands of men and women have culminated in this incredible accomplishment thus far. People have dedicated their entire life to making this possible, and you dismiss it all as if you are bored. If this American achievement bores you, then why are you even here commenting on this mission?

"probably unnecessary" testing? Would you rather have them just go ahead and launch the copter without going that last mile of precaution, after traveling millions of miles to get to this point? And then you make negative predictions of failure? Yes, the entire mission has the potential for failure - even getting into your automobile each day (if you have one) is subject to failure. Does that mean you therefore shouldn't even try to drive?

Perhaps it's just your eagerness to see it fly - I share that same desire with you - maybe I'm being too tough on you and if so, I apologize. It's just that I've been following NASA's missions since I was a very young boy, first with the Ranger missions that crash-landed on the moon, followed by the elegant Surveyor missions that soft-landed on the moon. These missions take time to ensure perfection. Please have more patience...

context: A helium balloon would have flown for months and would have help map winds at various altitudes

replies.context: balloons don't fly.
It wouldn't because of Mars' tenuous atmosphere.

Since the atmosphere of Mars is 95% carbon dioxide (heavier than air), an ordinary air balloon would provide lift - helium or hydrogen even more so. 

Since the atmosphere is so thin (less pressure), it would take much less gas to inflate a balloon of a given volume. 

But, since atmospheric pressure is much less, it would take a much larger balloon to contain enough gas so that the difference in the weight of the gas and the same volume of CO2 would be enough to provide a given amount of lift.

replies.context:
Your knowledge of basic science, and everything else apparently, is sadly lacking.

Mars HAS an atmosphere (mostly CO2), but it is less than 1 percent of Earth's, that's why it has dust storms that have been easily visible from Earth for over two hundred years, you need an atmosphere for wind.  The pressure on Mars is about the same as the air pressure on Earth at an altitude of 100,000 feet.  Given that Mars also has only a quarter Earth's gravity so needs less lift, a helicopter can readily fly in that low atmospheric pressure.

As to "no helicopter flying on Mars", they haven't launched it yet, they said they would in a couple of weeks.  The picture above is just an artist's rendering of what we can expect, and they don't claim it to  be anything otherwise.

It would be easier to put a man on  Mars and bring him home again than to pull off the enormous conspiracy of lies you‚Äôre talking about without leaving tons of actual evidence (meanwhile there‚Äôs zero evidence).
